messages.text: Which package folks here use for running Panel data models in Julia? I had a look at `FixedEffectModels.jl` but I want to run swamy-arora random effects estimators and the between estimators, too. For fixed effects this package works awesome though.

messages.text:
Hi folks,

Not sure if I am asking for a right thing but I was wondering if there is any good resource on learning Machine learning with economics connection? I have very less experience of ML stuff. It will be great if there is something which involves Julia, too (I feel, it must be very rare!).

elements.text:
Hi folks,

Not sure if I am asking for a right thing but I was wondering if there is any good resource on learning Machine learning with economics connection? I have very less experience of ML stuff. It will be great if there is something which involves Julia, too (I feel, it must be very rare!).

messages.text: I would start with <https://julia.quantecon.org/index_toc.html|quantecon> if you haven't already, then once you have a basic overview of how things interact, <https://sciml.ai/|sciml> would be the second step.

attachments.title: Table of Contents
attachments.text: This website presents a set of lectures on quantitative economic modeling, designed and written by Jesse Perla, Thomas J. Sargent and John Stachurski.
attachments.fallback: Quantitative Economics with Julia: Table of Contents

elements.text: if you haven't already, then once you have a basic overview of how things interact,

messages.text: I really want to take some time and investigate :microscope: sci-ml’s ecosystem on various econ DiffEQs. Particularly PINNs and Universal Differential Equations.

elements.text: I really want to take some time and investigate
sci-ml’s ecosystem on various econ DiffEQs. Particularly PINNs and Universal Differential Equations.

messages.text: Does anyone have any suggestions for a good model to start with (Should be a DiffEQ) and I don’t really want to do Solow.

elements.text: Does anyone have any suggestions for a good model to start with (Should be a DiffEQ) and I don’t really want to do Solow.

messages.text: I think you should only do this stuff with a particular application in mind.  For most of the things that economists (at least macro and finance) do things just don't fit into the existing frameworks... Even the toy problems aren't written up.  So I would focus on the economic problem ffirst and see how you would want to solve i.

elements.text: I think you should only do this stuff with a particular application in mind.  For most of the things that economists (at least macro and finance) do things just don't fit into the existing frameworks... Even the toy problems aren't written up.  So I would focus on the economic problem ffirst and see how you would want to solve i.

messages.text: But keep in mind that many things in economics are stationary problems and/or infinite horizon which changes the techniques you need.  Similarly, stofhastic vs. deterministic require very different techniques

elements.text: But keep in mind that many things in economics are stationary problems and/or infinite horizon which changes the techniques you need.  Similarly, stofhastic vs. deterministic require very different techniques
